title: Maximum Security Clearance
problem_statement:
Maximum Security Clearance

Problem Description

You're a cybersecurity engineer at a top-tier firm, tasked with a critical component of a new distributed secure encryption system. In this system, the data is stored at different security levels, represented as an m-bit integer. For certain high-privilege operations, such a full system-wide backup restoration, a process needs to acquire a 'Maximum Security Clearance'. This clearance is achieved when the bitwise OR of the security levels of a consecutive sequence of data chunks equals 2m - 1 (a bitmask with all m bits set to 1).

Your mission is to develop an efficient algorithm to identify the shortest possible continuous sequence of data chunks that collectively grant the Maximum Security Clearance.

Input Format

  • Each input contains multiple test cases. The first line contains a single integer t indicating the number of test cases.
  • The first line of each test case contains two space-separated integers, n and m, where n is the total number of data chunks and m is the number of bits representing the security level.
  • The second line of each test case contains n space-separated integers, a1, a2, ..., an, where ai is the security level of the i-th data chunk.

Output Format

  • For each test case, output a single integer representing the length of the shortest consecutive sequence of data chunks whose combined bitwise OR results in 2m - 1.
  • If no such sequence exists, output -1.

Constraints

  • t <= 104
  • 1 <= n <= 105
  • 1 <= m <= 20
  • 0 <= ai <= 2m - 1
  • The sum of n over all test cases does not exceed 5 * 105

Examples

Example 1:

Input:
1
3 3
1 2 4
Output:
3

Explanation: We need to get the max possible security level of (23 - 1) = 7 (which has all 1's in its binary representation). This can be achieved by using the consecutive elements of (1,2,4) as the bitwise OR of 1 (001 in binary), 2 (010 in binary) and 4 (100) in binary achieves the value of 7, and this is not achievable by any of the other shorter subsequences of the given array.

Example 2:

Input:
2
5 4
12 2 13 4 5
5 5
1 2 8 5 2
Output:
2
-1

Explanation: In the first testcase, the max possible security level of 15 (24 - 1) can be obtained by taking continuous elements 2 and 13, whose bitwise OR evaluates to 15.

In the second test case, none of the continuous subsequences of the given array have bitwise ORs evaluate to 25-1 = 31. As no continuous data chunks can give us the maximum security level, we report -1 as the answer.
